By examining Supreme Court decisions in light of works on American history, politics, and political theory, this class will explore legal, political, and philosophical debates on civil liberties today. Readings will consider litigation of the 1st, 2nd, 4th, 5th, 8th, and 14th Amendments. Issues will include struggles over freedom of religion, speech, privacy, and property rights, analyzed in the context of American cultural traditions and hierarchies along with conflicts over the rights of suspects, criminals and citizens, analyzed in the context of racial and class tensions, criminal violence, and anti-terrorist security.

Overall, students found this class very interesting. Students really enjoyed the lectures because Professor Smith tied together the information in different Supreme Court cases very well. In addition, he always tied what they were learning to current events and how they related to what was being taught. 
Students heaped praise on Professor Smith. One student claimed he was “hilarious and down-to-earth.” Most students said he was a very accessible teacher and did a great job connecting material from different lectures.
